abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>
                    Halophiles utilize two distinct osmoprotection strategies. The accumulation of organic compatible solutes such as glycine betaine does not perturb the functioning of cytoplasmic components, but represents a large investment of energy and carbon. KCl is an energetically attractive alternative osmoprotectant, but requires genome-wide modifications to establish a highly acidic proteome. Most extreme halophiles are optimized for the use of one of these two strategies. Here we examine the extremely halophilic Proteobacterium
                    <jats:italic>Halorhodospira halophila</jats:italic>
                    and report that medium K
                    <jats:sup>+</jats:sup>
                    concentration dramatically alters its osmoprotectant use. When grown in hypersaline media containing substantial K
                    <jats:sup>+</jats:sup>
                    concentrations,
                    <jats:italic>H. halophila</jats:italic>
                    accumulates molar concentrations of KCl. However, at limiting K
                    <jats:sup>+</jats:sup>
                    concentrations the organism switches to glycine betaine as its major osmoprotectant. In contrast, the closely related organism
                    <jats:italic>Halorhodospira halochloris</jats:italic>
                    is limited to using compatible solutes.
                    <jats:italic>H. halophila</jats:italic>
                    performs both de novo synthesis and uptake of glycine betaine, matching the biosynthesis and transport systems encoded in its genome. The medium K
                    <jats:sup>+</jats:sup>
                    concentration (~10 mM) at which the KCl to glycine betaine osmoprotectant switch in
                    <jats:italic>H. halophila</jats:italic>
                    occurs is near the K
                    <jats:sup>+</jats:sup>
                    content of the lake from which it was isolated, supporting an ecological relevance of this osmoprotectant strategy.
                  </jats:p>
title: A potassium chloride to glycine betaine osmoprotectant switch in the extreme halophile Halorhodospira halophila
